application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Recent research has aimed both to disentangle the cognitive mechanisms that support learning-particularly the roles of reinforcement learning (RL) and working memory (WM)-and to characterize the dynamic processes that govern decision-making during learning. These two endeavors were integrated with the reinforcement learning working memory Linear Ballistic Accumulator (RLWM-LBA) model. The RLWM-LBA offers a unified framework to investigate how RL and WM contribute to learning and how these processes unfold over time to shape choice behavior. Specifically, it remains unclear whether neural processes of evidence accumulation identified in perceptual decision-making are also present in learning and how such a process is associated with RL and WM. To address these questions, we analyzed electroencephalography (EEG) data from 510 participants performing a stimulus-response association task. Using a Bayesian hierarchical RLWM-LBA model combined with event-related potential (ERP) analyses, we explored whether neural signatures of RL and WM persist when captured with RLWM-LBA model and whether a neural signal of evidence accumulation, the centro-parietal positivity (CPP), could be identified within this learning context. Our findings confirm previous reports by identifying distinct neural correlates for RL and WM. Importantly, we demonstrate a neural signature corresponding to internal uncertainty about learned action policies that closely resembles CPP signals documented in perceptual and preference-based decisions. Further, we show that a neural CPP signal both improves model fit and is differentially linked to RL and WM across load. These results provide evidence that the neural dynamics of decision-making during learning adhere to established evidence accumulation mechanisms and highlight how RL and WM processes dynamically shape learning and choice behavior.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The temporal dynamics of decision making in learning contexts have been extensively studied by modeling how reinforcement-based value estimates are transformed into choices (Fontanesi et al., 2019;Frank et al., 2015;Miletić et al., 2021;Pedersen et al., 2017;Shahar et al., 2019). Sequential sampling models have been central to these efforts, which describe decision making as the accumulation of evidence until a decision threshold is reached (Brown & Heathcote, 2008;Ratcliff, 1978;Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008).

Much of what we currently know about the underlying neural dynamics of decision making has emerged from studies of perceptual decisions (Forstmann et al., 2016;Gold & Shadlen, 2007;. A candidate neural signature that builds gradually until a decision boundary is crossed has been identified across species, including humans and nonhuman primates, and recording techniques, including single-cell recording, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and electroencephalography (EEG) (O'Connell et al., 2012;Philiastides & Sajda, 2007;Shadlen & Newsome, 2001;N. Steinemann et al., 2024). EEG recordings in humans has identified the centro-parietal positivity (CPP) as a candidate eventrelated component reflecting a neural instantiation of evidence accumulation (Gherman et al., 2024;O'Connell et al., 2012;Pisauro et al., 2017;N. A. Steinemann et al., 2018;Twomey et al., 2015). Despite these advances in perceptual and to some extent preference based-decision making, the neural dynamics of evidence accumulation are largely unexplored in learning contexts where decisions are guided by feedback-driven internal value estimates. Specifically, it remains unknown whether the neural decision making processes in reinforcement learning mirror the neural accumulation dynamics observed in perceptual and preference-based tasks.

Parallel research has emphasized that learning, even when limited to simple stimulusresponse associations, involves multiple cognitive processes rather than a single reinforcement learning mechanism (Collins, 2018;Collins & Frank, 2012;Nicholas et al., 2022). The Reinforcement Learning-Working Memory (RLWM) framework has shown that working memory (WM) and reinforcement learning (RL) both significantly contribute to learning stimulus-response associations (Collins, 2018;Collins & Frank, 2018). Importantly, the RLWM framework has demonstrated that the balance and cooperation between RL and WM vary systematically with cognitive demands such as load and delay, highlighting the context-dependent dynamic interplay between these cognitive systems.

Recently, these complementary lines of research converged in the development of the RLWM-LBA model (McDougle & Collins, 2021). This integrated modeling framework combines the RLWM approach with the Linear Ballistic Accumulator (LBA) model (Brown & Heathcote, 2008), linking learning processes to the temporal dynamics of decision making. Using the RLWM-LBA model in combination with EEG we can now address two central questions: First, can neural correlates of evidence accumulation be identified in learning contexts? Second, how do RL and WM influence this neural accumulation process?

In the present study including data from a large (n=565) convenience based sample of healthy volunteers aged 11 to 43 years, we utilize a combined computational modeling and EEG approach to investigate these questions. We first replicate and extend previous results from a standard softmax RLWM model (Collins & Frank, 2018;Rac-Lubashevsky et al., 2023), confirming distinct neural signatures-both temporally and topographically-for RL and WM processes. Next, by analyzing EEG signals in conjunction with model-derived drift rates, representing the speed of evidence accumulation, we identify a CPP signal reflecting key characteristics of evidence accumulation. Specifically, we observe that trials characterized by lower drift rates show a prolonged and slower buildup rate and lower peak amplitude, closely aligning with known properties of accumulation-to-bound processes in perceptual decision making .

Moreover, we find that incorporating a model-naïve, trial-by-trial measure of CPP buildup rate improves the RLWM-LBA model's fit to choice and RT, providing support to the assumptions that the CPP reflects the rate of evidence accumulation. Finally, our analyses reveal that the relative contributions of RL and WM to the neural accumulation process shift systematically with cognitive load: the influence of RL increases while the influence of WM decreases as the number of stimulus-response associations to be learned increases. These results align with model-based predictions and further validate the dynamic interplay of cognitive systems described by the RLWM framework (Collins & Frank, 2012).

Together, our findings demonstrate that neural correlates of evidence accumulation underpin decision making in reinforcement learning tasks. Furthermore, by disentangling the roles of RL and WM, this study provides new insights into how multiple cognitive systems interact to guide choice behavior during learning. . Experimental task and RLWM-LBA model. A) Illustration of RLWM task. Participants learned to associate stimuli with keypresses (here represented as colors) through deterministic feedback. The number of stimuli to learn varied across blocks, thereby challenging working memory capacity. Adapted from (Master et al., 2020). B) Graphical illustration of the interaction of RL and WM in the RLWM model. The RLWM model assumes the WM module directly learns the stimulus-response association, but is subject to decay, while the RL module learns by updating values through reward prediction errors. The action policy  is a combination of value estimates from a proportion of the WM and RL modules, where the proportion w depends on the propensity to use WM and WM capacity. Adapted from (McDougle & Collins, 2021). C) Graphical illustration of the LBA model. The model assumes a race between accumulators, where the winning response and response time is defined by the accumulator first crossing the decision threshold b. Importantly, the RLWM-LBA model assumes the drift rate (s) for each response is defined by the value estimate pi. Adapted from (Brown & Heathcote, 2008). RLWM = reinforcement learning working memory, LBA = linear ballistic accumulator.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Data from the first session in two prospective cohorts from the ongoing Norwegian longitudinal Brainmint study (Frogner et al., 2025;Marjanovic et al., 2025;Voldsbekk et al., 2024;Wiker et al., 2025) were used. Data from 214 youths (71.1 % female) aged from 11 to 25 (mean = 17.8, SD = 2.63) were included from the youth cohort. Data from 351 women aged 22 to 43 (mean = 32.1, SD = 3.47) were included from the pregnancy cohort. The pregnancy cohort is part of a longitudinal study, following women before, during and after pregnancy. Only the first session of each participant from the pregnancy cohort was used. Participants were recruited through social media platforms, local advertisements in newspapers, and through collaborations with other research projects. Inclusion criteria were Norwegian language skills and fulfillment of MRI safety criteria, as the data collection also included MRI scanning.

Informed consent was obtained prior to participation. For participants under 16 years old, guardians provided informed consent on behalf of their children. All procedures were approved by the Norwegian Regional Committees for Medical and Health Research Ethics (REK South East, ref. no: 2019/943 and 2019/345).

div.head: Task
div.p: The RLWM task was presented using an MS-7816 computer (Micro-Star International Co., Ltd) with Windows 7 (Microsoft Corporation, 2009). Participants were comfortably seated 80 cm from a Benq xl2420t monitor (Benq Corp.) with a resolution of 1920 × 1080 and a refresh rate of 60 Hz. Stimuli were presented using the Psychophysics Toolbox (Version 3.0.11; Brainard, 1997;Kleiner et al., 2007;Pelli, 1997) running in MATLAB R2014a (The MathWorks, Inc.). Responses were given on a Cedrus RB-740 response pad (Cedrus Corporation). In total, the session consisted of five experimental tasks. The RLWM task was second in order, preceded by a 10 minutes resting state EEG-recording.

The RLWM task ( Fig 1A), originally described in (Collins & Frank, 2012) is a three-armed bandit task in which participants are instructed to learn the correct action to stimuli. Here we used an adapted version described in (Master et al., 2020).

The task consisted of 11 blocks, within which participants learned to associate one of three button presses to between 2 and 5 stimuli. The stimuli in each block corresponded to a different category of stimuli (e.g. sports, fruits, places etc.). Each stimulus was associated with only one action, and feedback was deterministic. Participants were shown the entire set of stimuli at the beginning of each block to familiarize themselves with them. Each stimulus was presented within each block in a pseudo-randomized order until the correct response was given 4 out of the last 5 trials, with a minimum of 9 and a maximum of 15 presentations.

Participants were instructed that a given stimulus-response association did not inform about another stimulus-response association within a block, such that for a block with 3 stimuli it was not necessarily the case that each stimulus was associated with a separate action, thereby preventing participants to infer the correct action for a stimulus based on knowing the correct action for another stimulus.

Stimulus presentation was preceded by a presentation of a fixation cross for 0.5 s. Stimuli were presented for 7 s during which a response could be given for the entire presentation. A response ended the stimulus presentation, which was followed by 0.75 s feedback presentation ("Correct" for correct trials and "Try again!" for error trials).

div.head: RLWM-LBA model
div.p: The RLWM model was developed to account for the contribution of working memory in learning tasks typically modeled only by a reinforcement learning model. The RLWM consists of an RL and WM module that are combined to inform choices. See (Collins & Frank, 2012, 2018Master et al., 2020) for model comparison identifying the RLWM as fitting observed choice better than simpler RL models. Here we use the recently described Reinforcement Learning Working Memory-Linear Ballistic Accumulator (RLWM-LBA) model (McDougle & Collins, 2021) ( Fig 1B, Fig 1C), which was developed as an extension from the RLWM to capture the dynamics of choice during learning with the LBA model (Brown & Heathcote, 2008). The separate RL and WM modules are introduced before describing how they are combined to capture choice dynamics with the LBA model.

div.head: RL module
div.p: In the RL module learning is assumed to follow the delta learning rule (Rescorla & Wagner, 1972), in which the expected reward of a stimulus and action on trial is updated based on the prediction error between observed and expected reward:
To capture potential neglect of negative feedback, the learning rate is reduced in proportion to a bias parameter following negative prediction errors:

The bias parameter was bound to between 0 and 1. A bias parameter of 1 indicates total neglect of negative feedback, whereas a value of 0 indicates an equal rate of learning from positive and negative prediction errors.
Probability of choosing an action for a given stimulus is captured by the softmax choice rule, which scales expected rewards to sum to 1 according to the sensitivity parameter :

div.head: WM module
div.p: The WM module is designed as a temporary storage with perfect updating, but with limited capacity and decay. The updating of rewards in the WM module follows the delta learning rule but with a learning rate set to 1:

The bias parameter is also calculated for (not shown). Given the delaysensitive nature of working memory, the RLWM includes a decay parameter which assumes expected reward for each trial decays toward the initial value of before having observed any outcomes (here set to be 1/ ) according to the decay parameter :
In the RL module, the probability of choosing action for stimulus is captured with the softmax choice rule:
Finally, the proportion of which the two modules inform choices is described by the mixing value :
Importantly, the value of depends on the capacity parameter and propensity to use WM :
Where is a value between 2 and 5 (number of stimuli within a block) and is a proportion (i.e. between 0 and 1) representing the individual propensity to use WM in selecting actions.

div.head: Choice dynamics
div.p: The standard RLWM model (Collins & Frank, 2012) captures choice probabilities of internal value estimates through softmax transformation. In the RLWM-LBA model choices and the RT of choice is captured with the LBA model ( Fig 1C). The LBA model captures decision between N alternatives as a race in which the winning alternative is the one that first crosses the decision threshold , which is the sum of starting point bias and the relative threshold . The decision process is assumed to start randomly within the range of 0 and the starting point bias . The speed of evidence accumulation for each decision is capture by the drift rate parameter . Lastly, time spent on stimulus encoding and motor response is captured by the non-decision time parameter .

Driven by the discovery that choice latency continues to decrease after choice performance asymptotes, McDougle and Collins (McDougle & Collins, 2021) incorporated a Shannon entropy transformation (Shannon, 1948) which captures the relative uncertainty regarding the specificity of action-mappings across each action a and stimuli k, prior to encoding the current trial's stimulus.

High uncertainty is associated with longer RTs (Hyman, 1953). Thus, if within a block the correct action is the same across stimuli, uncertainty is low and is associated with faster RTs, while if the correct action differs across stimuli uncertainty is high and is associated with longer RT.

The entropy measure , representing action-mapping uncertainty, is incorporated into the calculation of trial-by-trial drift rates through dividing it by the combined value estimate . In addition, the softmax-transformed choice probabilities are scaled with a scaling parameter to ensure value estimates are scaled to capture choice latency.

Finally, the likelihood of trial-by-trial choice and RT is estimated with the LBA probability density function using trial-by-trial estimates of internal uncertainties for each of the three response alternatives together with LBA-parameters of starting point bias , the relative threshold , variability in drift rate and non-decision time .

div.head: Model analysis
div.p: We modeled performance in the RLWM task with a hierarchical Bayesian model in STAN (Carpenter et al., 2017) via the cmdstanr package (Gabry et al., 2025) in R. A Bayesian framework allows for utilizing prior knowledge in the definition of prior distributions and insight into the uncertainty of estimates through the estimation of posterior distributions. A hierarchical approach estimates group and individual parameters simultaneously, which has been shown to improve parameter recovery for individual parameters, in particular with fewer data points (Ratcliff & Childers, 2015).

Due to the large sample size, we used the Variational Bayes method to approximate posterior distributions. The Variational Bayes method, in contrast to Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling, does not guarantee a perfect approximation of the posterior distribution, and cannot be used to assess convergence, but is orders of magnitude faster than MCMC methods. Group priors were set to be in the range of previously reported estimates for each parameter. Weakly informative group priors were set to be in the typical range of estimates for each parameter. Priors for mean estimates of the parameters were as follows:

Priors for standard deviations were all set to (0.1). To constrain the parameters , , , and between 0 and 1, we approximated individual-level parameters using the normal CDF (via Phi_approx) for the group-level prior. Subject-level parameters were estimated as deviations from the mean group parameter, inspired by (Fontanesi et al., 2019), in order to ensure exploration of parameter space for low between-subject variability. Priors for all subject-level parameters were set to (0,1). We used the LBA probability density function and random generation function created for Stan to respectively calculate the likelihood of parameters given choice and RT and to generate predicted choice and RT for posterior predictive checks (Annis et al., 2017). Inferred latent variables directly calculated in the model were used as trial-by-trial predictors in the single trial EEG analyses.

div.head: EEG EEG data acquisition
div.p: EEG was recorded at a sampling rate of 2048 Hz using 64 active Ag/AgCl electrodes (placed in a cap in accordance with the 10/5 international system) with a BioSemi ActiveTwo system amplifier (BioSemi B.V., Amsterdam). This system minimizes common mode voltages by using a driven right leg electrode. Electrode offset was maintained between -20 and 20 mV. In addition to the 64 cap electrodes analyzed in the current study, we also recorded data from 8 external electrodes: two electrodes placed approximately 1 cm left to the left eye and right to the right eye measured horizontal eye movements (electrooculogram; EOG); two external electrodes placed on the left iliac crest and right clavicle measured the electrocardiogram, ECG); two electrodes were placed on the left and right abductor pollicis brevis measured electromyographic activity related to manual responses).

div.head: EEG preprocessing
div.p: Continuous EEG data was first high pass filtered at 0.1 Hz using the eeglab firfilt_new funtion with default parameters, before using the eeglab cleanline plugin to attenuate elecrical line noise at 50 Hz (as well as harmonics up to 1000 Hz). Next, the data was downsampled to 512 Hz, and bad scalp channels were identified using the eeglab clean rawdata function and rejected if their mean correlation with neighboring channels was below 0.8 or the line noise relative to its signal was above 4 standard deviations. Excluded channels were finally interpolated, before low-pass filtering the data at 40 Hz and extracting epochs ranging from -1.5 to 3 seconds relative to stimulus presentation. Epoched data was next decomposed using independent component analysis (ICA -picard algorithm), and resulting independent components were assigned probabilities of representing brain activity or common EEG artifacts using IClabel. Components assigned probabilities > .30 of belonging to the class "brain" and > .50 of belonging to the class "other" were retained for further analysis as these criteria had previously been found to identify most artifactual components. Next, we imported key single trial parameter estimates from the computational models (e.g., reinforcement learning Q values) into the epoched datasets and removed trials with not to be included in the analyses (e.g., error trials or the first presentation of a stimulus within a block), as well as any trials with amplitudes exceeding +/-150 μV between 1 second prior to and 3 seconds after stimulus onset. Datasets with less than 50% of the original 468 trials remaining were excluded, leaving a total of 510 datasets for single trial EEG analysis (i.e. 55 of EEG datasets (9.7%) were excluded). Finally, we extracted epochs from -700 to 700 ms relative to stimulus onset (for stimulus-locked analyses) or relative to the response (for response-locked analyses).

div.head: Single trial EEG analysis
div.p: Single trial EEG analyses were conducted using linear modelling as implemented in the unfold toolbox (Ehinger & Dimigen, 2019). In brief, EEG voltages at all electrodes and timepoints were fitted by general linear models, where the EEG signal is modelled as the sum of a set of independent variables/predictors, plus random noise.

For the stimulus-locked analyses we fitted models that included a fixed intercept (modelling the grand average ERP across all trials), as well as three predictors modeling trial-totrial variability in set-size (ranging from 2 to 5 stimulus-response associations, delay (i.e., the number of trials since the last correct performance of this specific stimulus-response association) and reinforcement learning Q value. All these trial-specific predictors were ztransformed prior to being included in the EEG-analyses.

For the response-locked analyses we fitted models that included a fixed intercept (modelling the grand average ERP across all trials, as well as one predictor modelling trial-totrial variability in either drift rate or log-transformed reaction time. As for the stimulus-locked analyses, these trial-specific predictors were z-transformed before being included in the EEG analyses.

Each single-trial analysis resulted in a set of beta-weight (for each predictor) and these beta-weights were next aggregated at the group level, where we computed 20% trimmed mean ERPs (ensuring estimates robust against potential outlier values), and tested for statistical significance using trimmed mean t-tests. All resulting p-values were Bonferromni-corrected across electrodes (64), time-points (716) and estimated parameters (4 for stimulus-locked analyses, 2 for response-locked analyses), yielding a Bonferroni-corrected theshold of 2.73e-06.

div.head: Results
div.p: 565 participants performed the reinforcement learning working memory (RLWM) task, a stimulus-response association task where subjects learn to associate stimuli with one of three button presses. The RLWM task was designed to tax the capacity and decay of the WM system by manipulating the number of stimuli (2,3,4 or 5) to be learned within a block and by varying the delay between presentations of the same stimulus. EEG data was recorded while participants performed the task to assess neural correlates of WM and RL and their impact on choice dynamics. Data from 55 participants were excluded because the EEG data quality was deemed poor, resulting in a final sample of 510 participants (see Materials and Methods for details).

div.head: Behavioral results
div.p: Observed measures of performance on the RLWM task showed signs of involvement of both RL and WM. First, accuracy improved, and RT decreased with stimulus presentations (Fig 2), indicative of incremental learning as reflected in RL. Second, accuracy improved, and RT decreased more quickly in lower set sizes (Fig 2), indicative of the use of a working memory system which successfully kept stimulus-response associations active in lower set sizes but were challenged by capacity-limitations and decay for higher set sizes. Further corroborating evidence of the involvement of both RL and WM can be seen in the influence of delay, set size and time on accuracy (Fig S1).

div.head: Computational model Model Fit
div.p: Trial-by-trial choice and RT data from the RLWM task was analyzed with a hierarchical Bayesian version of the RLWM-LBA model (McDougle & Collins, 2021) (see distribution of parameter estimates in Fig S2). The model was shown to provide good fits to data, capturing the increased accuracy and decreased RT with stimulus iteration, and how these effects varied across set size (Fig 2). and reduction in RT with learning, and further that these effects are stronger in low compared to high set sizes.

div.head: Latent variables
div.p: Our main interest in the RLMW-LBA model here was to identify neural correlates of learning and decision making. To do so, we extracted model-inferred latent trial-by-trial variables of stimulusresponse associations (Q values) for both the RL and WM system and their combination into drift rates, reflecting the speed of evidence accumulation (Fig 3). Q values for the RL system were updated after feedback with the reward prediction error, scaled by learning rate. Q values for the WM-system assumed perfect updating, but values decayed after each trial to reflect memory decay. The combination of Q values from the two systems depended on estimated individual parameters of propensity to use WM vs RL and by WM capacity (see Materials and Methods for details). Trial-by-trial drift rates were used as predictors in the EEG analysis as a measure of relative uncertainty in stimulus-response associations, akin to choice difficulty in perceptual decision making tasks.

Value estimates from the RL system (Q-RL values) incrementally increased with learning, independent of set size (Fig 3A), while value estimates from the WM system (Q-WM values) and the combined drift rate estimates, reflecting the combined contribution of both the RL and WM system, were strongly dependent on set size (Fig 3B and 3C). and drift rate (C) values for the chosen option over stimulus iteration across set size. The predicted drift rate shows a strong effect of set size which aids in capturing the strong difference in RT. The small variation in Q-RL values across set size is driven by higher accuracy in lower set sizes, which aids trial-by-trial learning due to positive reinforcement.

div.head: EEG results
div.p: Our large cohort combined with the use of the RLWM-LBA model provided a platform to build upon prior research exploring the neural underpinnings of RL, WM and choice dynamics.

First, it enabled us to investigate whether neural correlates previously associated with the standard softmax RLWM model could be identified using the RLWM-LBA model, which also accounts for RT distributions. This validation aimed to assess the stability and consistency of neural signatures of RL and WM across different computational frameworks.

Second, leveraging the detailed trial-level drift rate predictions inferred by the RLWM-LBA model, we explored the possibility of detecting neural signals of evidence accumulation during instrumental learning-akin to the CPP signal established in perceptual decision-making contexts .

div.head: EEG correlates of WM and RL on learning
div.p: Previous studies used EEG to investigate the location and timing of variables related to RL and WM (Collins & Frank, 2018;Rac-Lubashevsky et al., 2023). Specifically, they investigated the effects of set size, delay (represented as the number of intervening trials since the last presentation of the current stimulus where a correct response was made) and the stimulusresponse value in the RL system for the chosen option.

Consistent with earlier studies (Collins & Frank, 2018;Rac-Lubashevsky et al., 2023), we found a prominent frontal negativity around 300 ms after stimulus-onset for Q values, as well as a similar pattern at the same time-point for delay (Fig 4). We also observed the previously described parietal positivity around 540 ms for effects of set-size. However, unlike these previous reports, we additionally observed an early frontal negativity for set-size.

Similar to (Rac-Lubashevsky et al., 2023) we found a late temporal component of Q-RL values. Also consistent with previous studies we found significant early frontal and parietal effect of delay, which was assumed to reflect the reduced utility and activation of the WM system for longer delays, when it is likely that the action value has decayed from the WM system.

div.head: EEG correlates of WM, RL and drift rate on choice dynamics
div.p: Our second aim was to search for a neural evidence accumulation signal for decisions in stimulus-response learning akin to the CPP component identified in perceptual decision making (Kelly & O'Connell, 2013. Several assumptions should be met for a neural signal to be deemed a potential evidence accumulation signal. First, activity should rise until a threshold is reached and this threshold should be close in time to the motor response. Further, there should be an effect of choice difficulty, in which activity should have an earlier onset and accumulate more slowly for more difficult and more prolonged decisions. In addition, several studies have found an effect of difficulty in peak amplitude, in which easier decisions peak at a higher threshold prior to motor response (Gherman et al., 2024;Kelly et al., 2021;Philiastides et al., 2014).
Based on previous studies we divided drift rate into quartiles. As there were strong effects of set size on drift rate (Fig 3C), we calculated quartiles and ran analyses separately for each set size.

div.head: Buildup of CPP scales with drift rate
div.p: Results from the response-locked analyses showed significant effects of drift rate, that were particularly pronounced for higher set sizes (Fig 5, left panels). Just prior to the response, the ERPs for higher set sizes showed a centro-partietal positivity, consistent with predictions for the CPP component (Fig 5 right panels). Figure 5. EEG effects of drift rate across set size. Inferred drift rates were divided into quartiles for each subject and set size. Q1 represents the trials with the least evidence for the chosen (correct) option. Figure 6. Inferred drift rates were divided into quartiles (Q) for each subject and set size. Q1 represents the trials with the least and Q4 the trials with the most evidence for the chosen (correct) option.

Inspection or the grand average ERPs from electrode CPz showed that this CPP response peaked close to response execution (Fig 6). Specifically for higher set sizes, the peak amplitude was higher for higher drift rates. Together, these results indicate the presence of a CPP signal during decision making in learning.

div.head: Trial-by-trial slope improves model fit
div.p: Next, we set out to investigate whether the buildup observed in the CPz could enhance the RLWM-LBA model's fit, which would further validate the CPP component as a candidate neural implementation of evidence accumulation (Frank et al., 2015;Pedersen & Frank, 2020). To calculate a CPP slope signal we extracted the amplitude from the CPz at -200 and -50 ms prior to response on each trial and calculated the slope on the contrast from these two timepoints. We then extended our baseline RLWM-LBA model by including the CPP slope as a regressor on the drift rate scaling parameter :

Thus, choice probabilities  were scaled with a scaling parameter  that varied from trialby-trial (t), dependent on the CPP slope regressor and regressor. This neurally informed model significantly improved model fit relative to the baseline model, which assumed a fixed scaling parameter  (elpd_diff: 1609, SE: 48.5). Additionally, the regression coefficient was positive and reliably different from zero (mean: 0.094, HDI (95%) = 0.077 -0.111), such that higher values of trial-by-trial neural indices of evidence accumulation increased the scaling parameter, directly predicting variability in the rate at which learned value estimates translates into decision evidence.

div.head: WM and RL differentially linked to CPP slope across set size
div.p: Finally, we explored whether value estimates from the RL and WM modules differentially relate to the rate of the proposed evidence accumulation process. To do so, we assessed the association of Q value estimates of RL and WM, calculated as quartiles separately for each set size, on the trial-by-trial CPP slope signal:

Both RL and WM value estimates were associated with CPP buildup rate ( Figure 6). The association was stronger in lower set sizes for WM and in higher set sizes for RL (Table S1), corroborating previous behavioral, computational and neural findings that WM contributes more to the decision signal when the number of items to remember is low and that the influence of RL increases with load (Collins, 2018;Collins & Frank, 2012, 2018Rac-Lubashevsky et al., 2023). Figure 6. Associations of Q-RL (red) and Q-WM (blue) quartiles on CPP slope across set sizes. Beta coefficients with 95 % highest density interval (HDI). The associations increased with set size for RL and decreased for WM, in line with assumptions of increased (decreased) influence of RL (WM) with load.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In 510 participants we investigated electrophysiological correlates of RL, WM, and choice dynamics using the RLWM-LBA model. Consistent with prior work using the softmax-based RLWM framework, we identified distinct neural signatures associated with RL and WM processes. Specifically, we partially replicated previously documented temporal and topographic dissociations between RL and WM components (Collins et al., 2017;Collins & Frank, 2018). We also note, however, that we observed more widespread effects than previously reported, including earlier effects for set-size. These partial discrepancies might be due to the considerably larger sample included in the current study.

Further, we identified a centro-parietal positivity (CPP) signal consistent with evidence accumulation processes previously described in perceptual and preference-based decisionmaking tasks (Gherman et al., 2024;Kelly & O'Connell, 2013;O'Connell et al., 2012). Our analysis revealed that CPP amplitude varied systematically with drift rate estimates from the RLWM-LBA model, such that lower drift rates were associated with prolonged and slower CPP buildup and lower peak amplitudes. These findings support the hypothesis that neural evidence accumulation processes are engaged during decision making in learning, where decisions reflect the internal uncertainty of learned action policies, rather than external sensory evidence. A recent study also found a CPP signal during internal sampling of evidence, in which participants remembered the direction of a previously presented stimulus in a working memory task (Van Ede & Nobre, 2024).

We did not find effects of modulation of CPP slope and amplitude by drift rate at lower set sizes. This may stem from rapid learning and associated ceiling effects, limiting the variability needed to clearly dissociate quartile differences. Participants quickly attained high accuracy under low load conditions, reducing variability in drift rates between quartiles. Despite this reduced variability, the consistent presence of a clear buildup to threshold signal in these conditions suggests that an accumulation-to-bound process is nonetheless active. Thus, the absence of strong quartile effects under low load conditions likely reflects a methodological limitation rather than an absence of neural accumulation dynamics per se.

There were strong effects of drift rate in the peak amplitude of activity. Other studies have reported similar results, for both perceptual and preference-based decision making (Kelly et al., 2021;Philiastides et al., 2014;N. Steinemann et al., 2024;N. A. Steinemann et al., 2018). This effect can be captured either with a collapsing boundary that decays with time (Drugowitsch et al., 2012;Tajima et al., 2016), or with an urgency signal which boosts the decision variable more with increased time (Thura et al., 2012;Yau et al., 2021). These hypotheses make similar predictions to the amount of evidence required to decide, namely that when uncertainty is high decisions should be based on less evidence, to avoid spending time on decisions with an uncertain outcome. Such mechanisms have also shown to be optimal (Drugowitsch et al., 2019), but were beyond the scope of the current study. Future work could explore whether collapsing bound or urgency signals could explain amplitude effects in the CPP to further refine the explanatory power of accumulation-to-bound models in reinforcement learning tasks.

We found that incorporating a trial-by-trial EEG-derived CPP buildup signal into the RLWM-LBA model improved model fit. This result demonstrates the utility of leveraging neural data to refine computational models of learning and decision dynamics (Frank et al., 2015;Kelly et al., 2021;Pedersen et al., 2021;Pedersen & Frank, 2020;Turner et al., 2013Turner et al., , 2019. Importantly, our analyses extend prior findings by showing that trial-level fluctuations in neural accumulation signals not only reflect but also actively inform the dynamics of decision-making during learning. Future studies could test whether implementing neural measures into the RLWM-LBA model as we did here improves association of computational phenotypes to measures of development and mental health (Cheng et al., 2024;Collins et al., 2017;Frogner et al., 2025;Master et al., 2020).

Our results also contribute to the ongoing discussion regarding the interplay between RL and WM systems (Collins et al., 2017;Collins & Frank, 2018;McDougle & Collins, 2021;Yoo & Collins, 2022). We observed that the relative contributions of RL and WM to decision-related neural dynamics varied systematically with cognitive load, where differences in Q values were more associated with the CPP buildup in lower set size for WM and higher set sizes for RL, reinforcing the concept of a cooperative yet dynamic relationship between these cognitive processes.

While our findings suggest a neural evidence accumulation mechanism during reinforcement learning, alternative interpretations warrant consideration (Frömer et al., 2024). For instance, CPP signals might partly reflect action monitoring (Li et al., 2019) or decision confidence (Lee et al., 2023) rather than pure accumulation per se. However, we emphasize that the identified CPP signal closely mirrors neural accumulation dynamics extensively validated in perceptual decision-making studies, where careful controls and targeted manipulations have systematically addressed and ruled out several alternative explanations (Gherman et al., 2024;Kelly & O'Connell, 2013;O'Connell et al., 2024;Twomey et al., 2015). Thus, although we cannot exclude contributions from other cognitive processes, the strong similarity in the temporal dynamics, topographical distribution, and decision-related modulation of the CPP identified here with studies on perceptual perceptual decision making lends support to our interpretation that the CPP reflects evidence accumulation processes during reinforcement learning.

Some methodological considerations should be acknowledged. Firstly, the current design did not include stimulus-onset jitter, potentially resulting in overlapping neural responses to stimulus presentation and evidence accumulation, complicating clear isolation of decisionrelated processes. Future studies employing jittered stimulus presentations could enhance the temporal specificity of CPP effects. Secondly, the model was suboptimal at capturing the evolution of RTs for incorrect responses. Although we note that only correct responses were included in the EEG analyses, this issue might be mitigated by the implementation of collapsing boundaries or urgency signals, which can capture how decisions with high uncertainty can result in fast responses (Hawkins et al., 2015).

In conclusion, by integrating EEG data with the RLWM-LBA modeling framework, our findings provide robust empirical support for a neural evidence accumulation mechanism underlying reinforcement learning decisions. This extends our understanding of choice dynamics in learning contexts and offers valuable methodological insights for future research exploring the complex interactions between multiple cognitive systems during learning.

figure.head: Figure 1
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. Experimental task and RLWM-LBA model. A) Illustration of RLWM task. Participants learned to associate stimuli with keypresses (here represented as colors) through deterministic feedback. The number of stimuli to learn varied across blocks, thereby challenging working memory capacity. Adapted from (Master et al., 2020). B) Graphical illustration of the interaction of RL and WM in the RLWM model. The RLWM model assumes the WM module directly learns the stimulus-response association, but is subject to decay, while the RL module learns by updating values through reward prediction errors. The action policy  is a combination of value estimates from a proportion of the WM and RL modules, where the proportion w depends on the propensity to use WM and WM capacity. Adapted from (McDougle & Collins, 2021). C) Graphical illustration of the LBA model. The model assumes a race between accumulators, where the winning response and response time is defined by the accumulator first crossing the decision threshold b. Importantly, the RLWM-LBA model assumes the drift rate (s) for each response is defined by the value estimate pi. Adapted from (Brown & Heathcote, 2008). RLWM = reinforcement learning working memory, LBA = linear ballistic accumulator.

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Model fit. Observed and predicted results for A) accuracy and B) response time (RT) for correct and incorrect choices across set sizes. The model captures the increase in accuracy

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: EEG effects of RL and WM. A) Stimulus-locked effects of set size, delay and rl Q across electrodes. B) Scalp maps of effects of set size, delay and Qrl-values at early (300 ms) and late (540 ms) after stimulus onset. Colored electrodes and time points show significant negative (blue) or positive (red) t-values (Bonferroni corrected across electrodes, timepoints and estimated model parameters), with the scale ranging from -30 to 30. EEG correlates of WM, RL and internal uncertainty on choice dynamics.

figure.head: Figure S2 .
figure.label: S2
figure.figDesc: Parameter estimates from RLWM-LBA model. Approximated posterior distributions (A) and scatterplots (B) of individually estimated parameters. A = starting point bias, b = relative decision threshold, eta = drift rate scaling parameter, phi = WM-decay, rho = WM-proportion, C = WM-capacity, pers = bias positive learning rate, tau = non-decision time, alpha = learning rate.

figure.head: Table S1 . Posterior distributions of difference on the association of RL and WM quartiles on CPP slope.
figure.label: S1

div.head: Supplementary Information
div.p: . Behavioral results indicating involvement of working memory. (A) Accuracy decreases with delay in higher set sizes, suggesting the decay in working memory. (B) and (C) Declining effects of delay and set size on accuracy over trials point to a shift from WM to RL as learning stabilizes.
